newsitem.title: MEXICO: Elephants, bloodsucker in debtors protest in Mexico.
newsitem.headline: Elephants, bloodsucker in debtors protest in Mexico.

text.p: A pair of elephants from two debt-ridden circuses and a man dressed up as a bloodsucker led a 4,000-strong march of debtors through the Mexico City centre on Monday to protest government economic and banking policies.

Two circuses, which said they were driven into default by recession and high interest rates, lent the elephants in a gesture they said represented the "disproportionate" surge in debts in Mexico since last year's economic crisis.

The march, which followed a three-day hunger strike by five Mexican debtors at the International Monetary Fund last weekend, marked a growing crescendo of protest against debt woes just as the economy has started picking up.
On Monday, the government extended a deadline for past-due mortgage debtors to put their situation to rights with the banks if they applied for a restructuring today.
But the million-strong El Barzon debtors movement said the move was insufficient.
"It is not enough to extend terms; we want real solutions that guarantee that next year there will be economic stability," Barzon leader Jose Gutierrez said.

A man masked as the "chupacabras", or goatsucker, a phantom-like creature said to attack goats and drink their blood, started a fast at the finance ministry and threatened to swoop down on loan officers seeking to foreclose mortgages.

The elephants, El Barzon said, were also in protest, lest their circus be closed down because of the burden of debt payments that have surged since interest rates soared during Mexico's 1994-1995 economic crisis.
